column1: The origins of the city began with being a fort town; General William Tecumseh Sherman sited what became known as Fort Sherman on the north shore of Lake Coeur d'Alene in 1878. Peopling of the town came when miners and prospectors came to the region after gold and silver deposits were found in what would become the Silver Valley and after the Northern Pacific Railroad reached the town in 1883. In the 1890s
column2: two significant miners' uprisings over wages took place in the Coeur d'Alene Mining District
column3: one which became motivation for the bombing assassination of former Idaho Governor Frank Steunenberg in 1905. The late 19th century discovery of highly prized white pine in the forests of northern Idaho resulted in a timber boom that peaked in the late 1920s and was accompanied by the rapid population growth which led to the incorporation of the city on September 4
column4: 1906. After the Great Depression
column5: tourism started to become a major source of development in the area and by the 1980s it became the major driver in the local economy after decades of heavy reliance on logging
column6: the city featured a more balanced economy with manufacturing

column1: The city of Coeur d'Alene has grown significantly since the 1990s
column2: in part because of a substantial increase in tourism
column3: encouraged by several resorts and recreational activities in the area and outmigration predominantly from other western states. The Coeur d'Alene Resort and its 0.75-mile (1.21 km) floating boardwalk and a 165-acre (0.67 km2) natural area called Tubbs Hill take up a prominent portion of the city's downtown. Popular parks such as City Park and Beach and McEuen Park are also are fixtures of the downtown waterfront. The city has become somewhat of a destination for golfers

The city has become known for having one of the largest Holiday Light Shows in the United States and hosting a popular Ironman Triathlon event and is home to the Museum of North Idaho and North Idaho College.

column1: The Coeur d'Alene people called themselves by the autonym Schitsu'umsh in Coeur d'Alene
column2: one of the Salishan languages
column3: meaning "those who are found here" or "the found ones". These Native Americans lived along the rivers and lakes of the region
column4: in a territory of 4
column6: 000 acres (16
column7: 000 km2) extending from eastern Washington to Montana; these tribes primarily located their villages and camps near food gathering or processing sites. The built environment of the camps featured conical lodges constructed from poles and mats sewn from tule or animal hides. The Coeur d'Alene people were hunter-gatherers following the seasonal cycles who practiced subsistence hunting of wild game and fishing during the salmon runs
column8: and then foraging for berries and other edibles along the shores of the regions numerous lakes and rivers. The introduction of the horse made hunting and transportation more efficient.

column1: The area was extensively explored by fur trader David Thompson of the North West Company starting in 1809 when he established the Kullyspell House trading post on Lake Pend Orielle.[a] Thompson
column2: who usually used native names to describe the places and people he came across for unexplained reasons ascribed the name of "Pointed Hearts" to one the tribes he traded with and "Pointed Heart Lake" for the lake they lived near. Since Thompson traveled with French-speaking Iroquois guides and scouts
column3: it has been speculated that they may have been the first to refer to the tribe as the Coeur d'Alene. As French was the spoken language of the Canadian fur traders
column4: it is likely that “pointed heart” has its origins in the French transliteration of Cœur or "heart"
column5: d’ or "in the middle of" and Alêne or "awl" meaning the tribal traders had hearts as sharp as the tip of an awl or sharp hearted and were shrewd
column6: tough businessmen.The Oregon boundary dispute (or Oregon question) arose as a result of competing British and American claims to the Pacific Northwest of North America in the first half of the 19th century. The British had trading ties extending from Canada and had started settlements in present-day British Columbia and at Fort Astoria on the Pacific coast near the mouth of the Columbia River. The Oregon Treaty of 1846 ended the disputed joint occupation of the area in present-day Idaho when Britain ceded all rights to land south of the 49th parallel to the United States. In another territorial dispute
column7: the U.S. government through Territorial Governor Isaac Stevens began to negotiate treaties that would begin to move the various tribes of the region onto reservation lands. These talks sparked armed hostilities between the native Coeur d'Alene
column8: Spokane and Palouse and the settler populations that resulted in an initial victory for the tribes at the Battle of Steptoe Butte but was followed up with George Wright's campaign that subdued the natives. The Coeur d'Alene Reservation is located in Benewah and Kootenai counties south of Coeur d'Alene in communities focused around Worley and Plummer.With the discovery of gold out west and the establishment of Idaho Territory in 1863
column9: there was an increase in settlers to the region. When General William Tecumseh Sherman was commander of the U.S. Army during the Indian Wars and following the defeat of General George Armstrong Custer at the Battle of Little Big Horn
column10: he erected several forts in the west. During a tour of the Inland Northwest on his way to Fort Walla Walla on the Mullan Road
column11: he was impressed by the scenery of the area and ordered a fort constructed on the lake in 1877 and gave it the name Fort Coeur d'Alene. The fort which gave the city its name was established in 1878 and the name of the fort was later changed to Fort Sherman to honor the general.

column1: Miners and prospectors came to the region after gold and silver deposits were found in the Coeur d'Alene mountains and the Northern Pacific Railroad came to the village in 1883. The village became the location where ore from the mining district was ferried and transferred to the rail lines from steamboats that traveled down from the Coeur d'Alene River from the Cataldo Mission. The township was officially incorporated by petition on August 22
column2: 1887. In the 1890s
column3: two significant miners' uprisings took place in the Coeur d'Alene Mining District
column4: where the workers struggled with high risk and low pay. In 1892
column5: the union's discovery of a labor spy in their midst
column6: in the person of Charlie Siringo
column7: a sometime cowboy and Pinkerton agent
column8: resulted in a strike that developed into a shooting war between miners and the company in Burke Canyon. When the mine owners planned to reduce wages depending on job duties to mitigate increased costs
column9: the miners declared a strike against the reduction of wages and the increase in work hours and demanded a "living wage" be paid to every man working underground–the common laborer as well as the skilled; in an era when many unions were AFL craft unions
column10: in which skilled workers frequently looked after their own kind
column11: this was an unusual circumstance—approximately three thousand higher-paid miners standing up for five hundred lower-paid "common" laborers. This principle of industrial unionism would animate Western hardrock miners for the next several decades. To restore order to the state of rebellion in Shoshone County
column12: Governor N. B. Willey declared martial law and sent federal troops to arrest and detain the union miners
column13: but not before dozens of casualties including six deaths and the destruction of the Frisco Mill. Years later Harry Orchard
column14: who owned a share of the Hercules Mine in the nearby mountains before it began producing
column16: brutal and little understood role in the Colorado Labor Wars. He later confessed to dynamiting a $250
column17: 000 mill belonging to the Bunker Hill Mining Company near Wardner during another similar miners' uprising in 1899. He later returned to Idaho to assassinate former Idaho Governor Frank Steunenberg in 1905. In the 1899 riot
column18: Steunenberg declared martial law and asked President William McKinley to send federal troops to quell the unrest.

Lake Coeur d'Alene is a natural dam-controlled lake that is 25 miles (40 km) long and 1 mile (1.6 km) to 3 miles (4.8 km) wide and fed by the Coeur d'Alene and Saint Joe Rivers. Although the Post Falls Dam on the Spokane River near Post Falls controls the lake levels
column14: the lake is usually kept at natural levels from January to June. To the immediate southeast is  Fernan Lake and to the northeast of the city is Hayden Lake and even further northeast in northern Kootenai County is Lake Pend Orielle which is among the largest and deepest natural lakes in the western United States with a surface area of 85
column15: 960 acres (347.9 km2) and maximum depth of 1
column16: 152 feet (351 m). The Coeur d'Alene Mountains of the Bitterroot Range rise to the east of the city to a maximum elevation of 7
column18: 241 m) at Cherry Peak.The wooded lands east of the city have been designated for protection and management as the Coeur d'Alene National Forest. The city is surrounded by lakes and forests that support a variety of wildlife. The large lakes in the Idaho panhandle attract birds on the Pacific Flyway and bird watching is popular on Lake Coeur d'Alene
column19: especially from November to February when bald eagles come annually to feed on the spawning kokanee. The Cougar Bay Nature Preserve on the northeast portion of Lake Coeur d'Alene is the closest and most accessible nature preserve for wildlife viewing

column2: depending on the definition

column5: characterized by a cold

column8: dry conditions in summer. The monthly daily mean temperature ranges from 29.8 °F (−1.2 °C) in December to 69.0 °F (20.6 °C) in July and August. Temperatures exceed 90 °F (32 °C) on 13 days per year
column9: only occasionally reaching 100 °F (38 °C)
column11: there may be several nights below 10 °F (−12 °C). Snowfall averages 32.4 inches (82 cm) per year and precipitation averages 25.68 inches (65.2 cm) per year and is generally lowest in summer. The average first and last freeze of the season are October 12 and May 3
column12: respectively. The city straddles the border between USDA Plant Hardiness Zones 6B and 7A. The Spokane–Coeur d'Alene area has many microclimates that can have different weather patterns and observations than the nearby official reporting stations used by the National Weather Service due to the diversity of the topography and other factors. For instance
column13: northern Idaho experiences more precipitation than eastern Washington from weather systems originating from the Pacific Ocean because it is on the windward side of the Rocky Mountains and also Coeur d'Alene can have noticeably milder nights and cooler days due to the moderating effect on the climate of large bodies of water such as Lake Coeur d'Alene.

column1: Coeur d'Alene like the state of Idaho as a whole is known for its conservative politics. In local
column2: state
column3: and federal elections
column4: the city and Kootenai County vote reliably conservative and are sometimes noncompetitive or uncontested. This wasn't always the case and some believe that this increasingly rightward trend is among other things a result of demographic shifts in the county that have altered the political landscape of the community and is a part of a general nationwide ideological polarization trend. North Idaho had once been a largely progressive district that was populated by a significant proportion of union laborers that worked the mines in the Silver Valley that had moderated particularly in the 1980s after mine and mill closures and union busting to then have more competitive elections until the late 20th century. Coeur d'Alene is among a small group of cities in the United States that has elected a socialist mayor
column5: electing John T. Wood
column6: a Socialist Party of America member to office in 1911 on a campaign platform of clean water
column7: better health and sanitation standards
column8: and anti-corruption. Since the high growth period beginning in the 1990s
column9: continuing outmigration of conservatives from the west coast states has made elections in the two-party system less competitive over time as the ever newer residents see the city as a place that represents their social and political values
column10: which are sometimes more conservative than the city as a whole. Many of the new migrants to the state of Idaho came from California
column11: which accounted for over half the net in-migration between 1992 and 2000 and three of the top four counties that had out-migration to Kootenai County were from the birthplace of modern American conservatism in southern California–San Diego

column22: 000 people in north Idaho in 2010.Companies that have their head offices in Coeur d'Alene include mining company and owner of the Lucky Friday mine in Mullan
column23: Hecla Mining and the U.S. operations of Canada-based restaurant
column25: Buck Knives is the most recognizable brand name in the area
column26: where they relocated the head office and factory from San Diego to the Coeur d'Alene suburb of Post Falls in 2005. In 2017
column27: the Coeur d'Alene metropolitan area had a gross metropolitan product of $5.93 billion. The Coeur d'Alene metropolitan area has a workforce of 80
column28: 000 people and an unemployment rate of 6.8% (as of June 2020); the largest sectors for non-farm employment are trade
column32: and education and health services as well as leisure and hospitality.The average commute to work is 18.5 minutes. Commuting across the state line into Washington is not uncommon. A concern for the city however is that the rising minimum wage and salary differential between Washington and Idaho will cause local personnel shortages.

column2: the Museum of North Idaho located in downtown Coeur d'Alene chronicles the history of the region. The museum was established in July of 1973 and permanent exhibits include "Schitsu'umsh
column3: “The People Who Were Discovered Here" which explores the lives of the Coeur d'Alene people
column4: "The Mullan Road" which commemorates Idaho's first road through the Fourth of July Pass
column5: "The Scandinavians Settled Here" which examines the Nordic influences on Coeur d'Alene
column6: and "Steamboats"
column7: which displays artifacts and photographs of the steamboats that used to cruise the lake. The museum does walking tours of the Fort Sherman grounds and also rents out the Fort Sherman chapel
column8: the oldest building in the city as a wedding venue. Other museums in the region include the Bird Aviation Museum and Invention Center located north of the city in Sagle and the Wallace Mining Museum to the east in Wallace. The Bird Aviation Museum and Invention Center is an aviation museum founded by Forrest Bird. The museum features a rotating number of approximately 20 aircraft dating from pre-World War I to the present. The Wallace District Mining Museum documents and recounts the legacy of over a century of mining history in the region. Mine tours are offered in the Sierra Silver Mine in Wallace and the Crystal Gold Mine in nearby Kellogg.

column1: There are many events and activities that can be enjoyed in and around Coeur d'Alene year round but most occur during the warm summer months. Annual community events that the city has big turnouts for include the Fourth of July Festival and the Holiday Light Show that begins at the end of November. Coeur d'Alene has been known for hosting big Fourth of July celebrations since its early days as a fort town. The Fourth of July Festival usually includes a parade down Sherman Avenue
column2: food and craft vendors
column3: carnival rides
column4: and live music and entertainment. Many watch the fireworks by the waterfront and beach; the Coeur d'Alene resort offers fireworks cruises that depart from Independence Point. The Holiday Light Show festivities are kicked off at the end of November and the lights are on display until January 1. The event also begins with a parade down Sherman Avenue and ends with a fireworks show; the resort's light show features over 1.5 million bulbs and the resort offers “Journey to the North Pole” cruises. The light show was named in USA Todays list as one of the best public holiday lights displays in the country in 2019. Another event in the winter months that often gets media attention is the Polar Bear Plunge every year on January 1. Event participants run into the cold waters of Lake Coeur d'Alene at Sanders Beach.One of the most well attended events in the region is Art on the Green
column5: the Street Fair
column6: and Taste of Couer d'Alene
column7: which are all held at the same time on the first weekend in August on the North Idaho College campus
column8: downtown Coeur d'Alene
column9: and City Park. Art on the Green is an outdoor arts and crafts festival and Street Fair is a shopping festival and the Taste of Coeur d'Alene is a food festival which has an annual attendance of about 60
column10: 000 people. Other popular events include Brewfest and the North Idaho State Fair.

column1: The natural environment allows many activities to be enjoyed. The biggest natural attractions and parks in and around the city include Tubb's Hill
column2: City Park and Beach
column3: and McEuen Park all near downtown.

column1: Tubb's Hill is a 120 acres (49 ha) park that is bordered by downtown Coeur d'Alene and McEuen Park to the north and the by Lake Coeur d'Alene on the south
column2: east
column3: and west sides. The park features a somewhat rugged 2.2 miles (3.5 km) interpretive trail that offers excellent views of the lake and the city. People often cliff jump into the lake from outcroppings in the park. The City Park occupies 17 acres (6.9 ha) in total along the lake shore near downtown and features 16 acres (6.5 ha) of beach with a tree lined promenade
column4: beach volleyball courts
column5: basketball courts
column6: public drinking and restrooms and shower facilities
column7: picnic tables and a large picnic shelter for events
column8: and a Fort Sherman themed playground for children. McEuen Park
column9: which reopened in 2014 after a remodel
column10: is a 22.5 acres (9.1 ha) park just north of Tubb's Hill that has a large playground
column15: and an off leash dog park. It also features a large pavilion and grassy amphitheater with concessions and restrooms for hosting large events as well as a boat launch and mooring facilities. The popular Kroc Center
column16: a multi-use venue with an aquatics center
column17: a fitness and recreation center as well as educational arts
column18: and wellness programs is located near Ramsey Park just north of the Village at Riverstone.

column1: The North Idaho Centennial Trail  and Trail of the Coeur d'Alenes are also popular attractions for outdoor activities. The North Idaho Centennial Trail is a continuation of the 60 miles (97 km) Spokane River Centennial Trail that runs between the Nine Mile Recreation Area in Washington and Higgins Point on the north shore of Lake Coeur d'Alene in Idaho. The Trail of the Couer d'Alenes is a 73 miles (117 km) rail trail that runs between Plummer
column2: Idaho and Mullan and passes near Heyburn State Park
column3: Harrison
column4: and Cataldo Mission State Park along the way. Heyburn State Park is the oldest park in the Pacific Northwest and is a popular camping and recreation area in southern Kootenai County along Lake Coeur d'Alene. The Cataldo Mission is a former mission established by the Jesuits and is a national historic landmark that is the site of the oldest building in the state of Idaho. Another popular rail trail in the region and near the terminus of the Trail of the Coeur d'Alenes is the Route of the Hiawatha. Also
column5: to the northeast of the city is Farragut State Park on the grounds of the former Farragut Naval Training Station at the edge of Lake Pend Orielle and in the Selkirk Mountains near the Montana border is a popular regional natural area for hiking
column6: Scotchman Peak
column7: where wild mountain goats can be seen.

column1: Coeur d'Alene has become a destination for golf enthusiasts. The city is home to five golf courses and there are another eight more within 20 miles (32 km). Coeur d'Alene Resort Golf Course is considered one of the best resort courses in the United States. Its 14th hole features the world's only movable floating green. There is also the Circling Raven Golf Club at the Coeur d'Alene Casino resort
column2: which has received praise as well as several other private courses nearby
column3: such the Tom Fazio-designed Gozzer Ranch. The Coeur d'Alene Public Golf Club is likely one of the most played courses in the area.

column1: Coeur d'Alene hosts some sporting events
column2: and the event that receives the most attention is most likely the Ironman Coeur d'Alene. The Ironman Triathlon alternates between full and half distance Ironman events on a rotating basis from year to year. The course takes athletes takes athletes through a 2.4-mile (3.9 km) double-loop swim in Lake Coeur d'Alene before transitioning to a 112-mile (180 km) double-loop bike course that is routed along the lake and then through the countryside and finally ends in a 26.2-mile (42.2 km) multiple-loop run through McEuen Park to a finish in downtown on Sherman Ave. Other less intense and rigorous athletic events in town include the 15–108 mi (24–174 km) Coeur d'Fondo bike race and the Coeur d'Alene Crossing
column3: a 2.4-mile swimming challenge where participants attempt to cross the lake. The Coeur d'Alene marathon is held annually at the end of May on the North Idaho Centennial Trail.In high school team sports
column4: there is an annual rivalry game between the Coeur d'Alene High School Vikings and Lake City High School Timberwolves called the "Fight for the Fish". The schools are the only two high schools in the city and both compete in Idaho's Inland Empire League (5A).

column1: Library services for the city of Coeur d'Alene are met by two public libraries
column2: the Coeur d'alene Public Library in downtown and the Lake City Public Library near Lake City High School. The Community Library Network maintains seven libraries in the wider communities in Kootenai and Shoshone counties
column3: including branches in Post Falls
column4: Hayden
column5: Rathdrum
column6: Spirit Lake
column7: Athol
column8: and Harrison. Public library services in the area trace its roots to the Coeur d'Alene Women's Club in October 1904 and its operations and funding responsibilities were taken over by the city in May 1909.The Coeur d'Alene School District#271 serves around 11
column9: 000 students in 18 schools which includes two traditional high schools
column13: and a dropout retrieval school. The first high school in the city
column14: Coeur d'Alene High School had its first building to house the students completed in 1904 and a second high school
column15: Lake City High School was opened in 1994. District students who qualify are also eligible for dual enrollment with North Idaho College and the University of Idaho. Also on offer in the district are magnet schools that focus on specific curricula such as the Sorensen Magnet School of the Arts and Humanities and Ramsey Magnet School of Science elementary schools and the Fernan STEM Academy

column1: The district is the sixth largest in the state and second largest employer in Kootenai County. Coeur d'Alene also has a charter school
column2: the Coeur d'Alene Charter Academy.

column1: Post secondary education is fulfilled by North Idaho College
column2: a public community college founded in 1933 as the Coeur d'Alene Junior College in downtown Coeur d'Alene on the former site of Fort Sherman. The college has an enrollment of about 6
column3: 000 students and has outreach branches in Kellogg
column4: Sandpoint
column5: and Bonners Ferry. The University of Idaho has a Coeur d'Alene presence and has a research park in the area.

column2: the city roads are oriented in the four cardinal directions
column3: with roads going north–south being designated as "streets" and roads going east–west as "avenues". Sherman Avenue divides the streets into north and south and Government Way divides the avenues into east and west. Major east-west thoroughfares include Sherman Avenue and Harrison Avenue and major north–south thoroughfares include U.S. Route 95
column4: Government Way
column5: 15th Street
column6: and Ramsey Street. Coeur d'Alene is accessed from Interstate 90 at Exits 11 through 15. Not too far to the east on I-90 is the Fourth of July Pass and further east near the Montana border is Lookout Pass that traverse the Rocky Mountains near Mullan. Before the construction of I-90
column7: the city was served by U.S. Route 10
column8: which ran through downtown; this route is now Northwest Boulevard and Sherman Avenue. The former US 10
column9: between I-90 exits 11 and 15
column10: is now designated as Interstate 90 Business. Interstate 90 was completed on October 14
column11: 1960 and dedicated by Governor Robert E. Smylie ten days later as the states first major interstate highway project to be completed. Major state highways in the area include Idaho State Highway 41 and U.S. 95. Idaho State Highway 41 has its southern terminus in Post Falls and is routed from I-90 northward to the Newport
column13: where it is in the vicinity of U.S. Route 2 and Washington State Route 20 and U.S. 95 runs north to south across the whole of western Idaho
column14: connecting the city with Sandpoint to the north and Moscow and Lewiston and eventually Boise to the south. Originally an exclusively in-state highway when it was proposed by the United States Numbered Highway System in 1925
column15: spanning from the Canadian border to Payette
column16: it is significant for connecting the long disconnected northern panhandle to the rest of the state; prior to the construction of U.S. 95
column17: one would have to travel through Washington and Oregon for passage to avoid the mountainous topography. Lincoln Way is designated U.S. 95 through the Coeur d'Alene area where it is an arterial street serving the suburbs to the north.

column1: The greater Coeur d'Alene area is almost entirely dependent upon private automobiles for transportation
column2: the city has a Walk Score of 36
column3: indicating most errands require a car. Combined with the city's rapid growth since 1990
column4: relative congestion now occurs on a significant portion of the area highways
column5: notably U.S. 95 between Northwest Blvd. north to Hayden. The average commute to work is 18.5 minutes.

column1: Public transportation played a significant role in Coeur d'Alenes' early growth as a tourist destination. When an interurban electric railroad line was completed in 1903 from Spokane to the city
column2: Inland Northwest residents often flocked to Lake Coeur d'Alene to enjoy being on the lake and going on steamboat cruises and other activities. The interurban electric line would later become the Spokane and Inland Empire Railroad. The steamboats on Lake Coeur d'Alene were not only used to transport goods such as ore and timber
column3: but also people. More steamboats operated on Lake Coeur d'Alene than on any other lake west of the Great Lakes and there were intense rivalries between the steamboat lines. The electric railroad and steam navigation on Lake Coeur d'Alene lasted until the late 1930s.[c]Today
column4: free public bus service is available to area residents
column5: provided by Citylink. Citylink buses operate in the urbanized area of Kootenai County
column6: leaving the Riverstone Transfer Station main hub every sixty minutes
column7: seven days a week
column8: including holidays. Buses are wheelchair-accessible and can transport up to two bicycles. The bus system comprises four separate routes:

column1: Urban Route B which serves Post Falls
column2: Hayden and West Coeur d'Alene
column3: Urban Route C which serves Downtown Coeur d'Alene
column4: Fernan and Hayden
column5: Rural Route
column6: which serves the towns of Worley
column7: Plummer
column8: Tensed
column9: and De Smet; and the Link Route
column10: which connects the two transfer stations at Riverstone and Worley. Extension of Spokane Transit Authority service into Idaho
column11: mainly an hourly express bus to and from Coeur d'Alene
column12: was originally proposed as part of the 2015 "STA Moving Forward" ballot measure
column13: the ballot measure eventually passed and service is expected to commence in 2025.

column1: The closest major airport serving Coeur d'Alene and North Idaho is Spokane International Airport
column2: which is served by six airlines and is 40 miles (64 km) to the west in Spokane
column3: Washington. The Coeur d'Alene Airport – Pappy Boyington Field (KCOE) serves as a general aviation airport in Hayden
column4: north of the city near U.S. 95. In 1941
column5: the Coeur d'Alene Chamber of Commerce promoted the purchase of 720 acres (290 ha) of land on the Rathdrum Prairie for the runway. The facility was built in 1942 by the Army Corps of Engineers at a cost of over $400
column6: 000. The Coeur d'Alene airport was designated as an alternate airport to Weeks Field (now the site of the Kootenai County Fairgrounds) in the event of an Axis invasion; the Weeks Field airport was used to train pilots during World War II.Near the marina on Lake Coeur d'Alene is the Brooks Seaplane Base
column7: which is a city-owned
column8: public-use seaplane base that is used for general aviation
column9: mostly air taxi purposes to conduct tours of Lake Coeur d'Alene and Lake Pend Orielle.

column1: The city of Coeur d'Alene provides billing services for municipal water
column2: sewer and stormwater management
column3: street lighting
column4: garbage collection
column5: and recycling; Avista Utilities provides both power and natural gas services in the area. The city draws its water supply from the Spokane Valley–Rathdrum Prairie Aquifer. Telecom services such as television
column6: internet
column7: and telephone service are provided by a variety of vendors including Frontier Communications
column8: Spectrum
column9: Time Warner
column10: and TDS Telecom.The Post Falls hydroelectric dam on the Spokane River was built in 1906 and has a generation capacity of 14.75 megawatts.

column1: Kootenai Health is the primary medical center serving the Coeur d'Alene and north Idaho communities. The hospital has 297 beds
column2: is a Level III trauma center and is the largest employer in Kootenai County. Coeur d'Alene also has a Veterans Affairs Community Based Outpatient Clinic (CBOC)
column3: the North Idaho CBOC
column4: which has the Mann-Grandstaff VA Medical Center in Spokane as a parent facility.

column1: Coeur d'Alene is part of the Spokane
column2: Washington TV and radio media market and receives broadcasts in the Pacific Time Zone. Coeur d'Alene is the city of license for some television and radio stations in the broadcast area such as Idaho Public Television station
column3: KCDT. In print media

column5: The Spokesman–Review
column6: but the city has its own daily newspaper
column7: the Coeur d'Alene Press which covers local issues to north Idaho and has an estimated circulation of about 17
column8: 300. The publication was founded in 1892 by Joseph T. Scott and printed their first issue on February 20 of that year. The newspaper is among the properties of the Hagadone Corporation which is run by Duane Hagadone.

column1: ^[a] Lewis and Clark noted the likely first contact between the Coeur d'Alene people and European Americans in a trade encounter at a Nez Perce camp on their expedition in 1805; along with trade goods
column2: the trappers unwittingly brought diseases that decimated the native population by about 80 percent.^[b] The U.S. government decided to close Fort Sherman and build Fort George Wright in Spokane in part due to the persistent flooding of the banks on Lake Coeur d'Alene.^[c] The popularity and convenience of the automobile and better road infrastructure led to the decline in other modes of transportation. Some steamboats were deliberately set ablaze for 4th of July celebrations in the late 1930s.
